Theologian, Confessor
Ambrose of Alexandria(before 212 c. 250) was a friend of theChristiantheologianOrigen. Ambrose was attracted by Origen's fame as a teacher, and visited theCatechetical School of Alexandriain 212. At first agnosticValentinus (Gnostic)ValentinianandMarcionismMarcionist, Ambrose, through Origen's teaching, eventually rejected this theology and became Origen's constant companion,Origen,Epistle to Sextus Julius Africanusvol. i. p. 29and was ordaineddeacon.Jerome's De Viris Illustribus# 61.Eusebius,Church History (Eusebius)Historia Ecclesiasticavii. 18He plied Origen with questions, and urged him to write his Commentaries (langgrcἐργοδιώκτης) on the books of theBible, and, as a wealthy nobleman and courtier,he provided his teacher with books for his studies and secretaries to lighten the labor of composition.S. Epiph.adv. Haer.64. [44] 3

He suffered during the persecution under the Roman emperorMaximinus Thraxin 235.Eusebius of Caesarea,Church History, 6.18.He was later released and died aconfessor.cite webRabensteinKatherineAmbrose of Alexandria (AC)Saints O' the Day for March 17March 1998http://www.saintpatrickdc.org/ss/0317.shtml2007-04-30http://web.archive.org/web/20070206151558/http://www.saintpatrickdc.org/ss/0317.shtml2007-02-06The last mention of Ambrose in the historical record is in Origen'sContra Celsum,which the latter wrote at the solicitation of Ambrose.

Origen often speaks of Ambrose in affectionately as a man of education with excellent literary and scholarly tastes. All of Origen's works written after 218 are dedicated to Ambrose, including hisOn Martyrdom,Contra Celsum,Commentary on St. John's Gospel, andOn Prayer.cite encyclopediaChristieAlbany JamesAlbany James ChristieAmbrosius Alexandrinus[[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]][[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]]1139[[Little, Brown and Company]]Boston1867http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0148.htmlAmbrose's letters to Origen (praised byJerome) are lost, although part of one exists.Routh,Reliquiae Sacr.ii. p. 367
article.heading: Veneration
article.paragraph: Ambrose is venerated as a saint by some branches of Christianity. His feast day in theRoman Catholic Churchfalls on 17 March.
